title: How Do I fight invalid lien on my home title?
question: 2009 I defaulted on my house and i owned some Home owners associations fees.
answers:
The responses above are correct and here's how you need to view this:

when you say "a lien was put on your new property," do you mean that the HOA recorded something new in 2019, and do you have a copy of that new recording showing the date of recordation?

Because this could simply be a result of an abstract recorded years ago.

Sonoma County Clerk-Recorder allows some online searching so you may be able to figure it out just by surfing around the Recorder's website.

Whether you owned real property at the time of the creditor's judgment, and the timing of the judgment and its recording matters.

If you owned real property at the time of the judgment being recorded (2013) and you subsequently filed for chapter 7 bankruptcy (2016), then the recording of the judgment would have created a secured lien --- attorneys here would confirm this: all liens on real property survive bankruptcy UNLESS additional legal work is completed to avoid the secured lien during the bankruptcy case (a lien / recorded instrument attaches to the thing rather than merely creating personally liability for you, which was discharged in your bankruptcy case).

This may not be the correct fact pattern, however, since it is slightly ambiguous from your questions.

Ultimately, either your former attorney or a new attorney should analyze precisely what occurred. Attorney Hill's analysis may also be correct (no lien created/no lien survived your bankruptcy filing), in which case simply providing the title company with your discharge paperwork and an explanation may be enough. If not, however, you'll need to talk to a bankruptcy lawyer for help.

Best of luck!

I agree with attorney Hill. She is giving you a very thorough response to your question. If you still have questions get in touch with your previous attorney. If you don't have a bankruptcy attorney use the avvo feature find a lawyer. Good luck.

By "defaulted" on your house, do you mean it was foreclosed on? If so, the abstract of judgment would have been an unsecured debt when you filed in 2016, and would have been discharged. If the title company or credit agency is now showing the pre-bankruptcy lien on a Post discharge asset, the title company needs to correct the title. You can provide a copy of your bankruptcy petition, list of creditors and discharge to the title company/ credit agency to correct the information.

While I suspect the lien by the HOA is a result of the filing of an abstract pre petition, if the abstract was filed POST petition, it would have been filed in violation of the bankruptcy discharge, and could subject the HOA to sanctions. Without knowing when the actual filing occurred, I don't know whether that is appropriate. More than likely, as I indicated, the title company/credit agency looked at the public record, saw the abstract and noted it incorrectly.
If you continue to have issues, talk to your bankruptcy attorney.
